bibl.title: Letter from S.J. Denno to Wickliffe Rose, December 13, 1922

div1.p: Denno describes the unusual yellow fever case of seaman John Cose. Denno would like Noguchi to examine Cose in New York.

div1.head: Letter from S.J. Denno to Wickliffe Rose, December 13, 1922
div1.opener:
COPY
STANDARD OIL COMPANY
Medical Dept.
26 Broadway
New York, December 13, 1922
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director
International Health Board
61 Broadway, New York City.
My dear Dr. Rose:
div1.p:
I am in receipt of a communication from our local Medical Director at
Tampico in which he writes as follows:

"The Master informed me that the wireless operator, John Cose, had com-
plained of feeling ill, but that he did not think that there was much the
matter with him. Upon entering his cabin I saw at once that I had a very
sick man, also that it looked very much like yellow fever. He was so ill
that I made no examination aboard but removed him to the hospital at once.

"As he had been taken ill one day after leaving Charleston, it appeared
impossible for him to have yellow fever. Our examination showed that he
had an intense acute nephritis, an irregular temperature, yellow skin and
bleeding gums. It seemed so impossible, that I decided to hold him under
observation. The case was shown to Drs. Cuaron and Scannell. They both
agreed that it was clinical yellow fever. He entered convalescence December
2nd. His condition was then such that I felt confident that our diagnosis
was correct.

"The “H.H. ROGERS” arrived at Tampico November 12th, proceeded to Santa
Margarita (the New England terminal, about seven miles up the Panuco River),
finished loading there the morning of the 13th, and proceeded to the wharf
at our refinery. Sailed for Port Lobos the morning of the 14th. Left Lobos
the 15th for Charleston, sailed from Charleston for Tampico November 23rd.
Cose was taken sick November 24th. These dates seem to make it impossible
for the infection to have taken place at Tampico. The only explanation that
I can give is that an infected mosquito boarded the ship here. Yellow fever
has not been known at either Santa Margarita or the Refinery. The whole
thing is impossible - but we have the case.

“I am requesting the Marine Department to return Cose to New York, and
that he be taken to you, and if you agree, to have him sent to Dr. Noguchi
for the test that he makes - the same that he did in the case of Tregar.”

With reference to the last paragraph of the Doctor's letter, I am
wondering whether Dr. Noguchi would care to see Mr. Cose, and if so when and
where it would be convenient to have Mr. Cose report.
